questions.text: All of the following is true about dashboard injury except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is associated with posterior dislocation of the hip

options.label: B
options.text: Sciatic nerve may be involved leading to foot drop

options.label: C
options.text: Avascular necrosis of the hip could be a late complication

options.label: D
options.text: The point of impact is on the greater trochanter

questions.correct_answer: D. The point of impact is on the greater trochanter
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The point of impact is on the greater trochanter

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A: It is associated with posterior dislocation of the hip. True. Posterior hip dislocation is classically associated with dashboard injury. The direction of impact is along the long axis of femur, forcing the femoral head out of the acetabulum and moves backwards.
  • • Option A:
  • • It is associated with posterior dislocation of the hip.
  • • Option B: Sciatic nerve may be involved leading to foot drop. True. In posterior dislocation of hip, the sciatic nerve gets commonly injured. It has two terminal branches – Tibial nerve and Common Peroneal Nerve. It is the common peroneal nerve which controls the muscles for dorsiflexion of foot. Injury to these fibers lead to foot drop.
  • • Option B:
  • • Sciatic nerve may be involved leading to foot drop.
  • • Option C: Avascular necrosis of the hip could be a late complication . True. Due to the damage to the network of reticular vessels in the femoral head, there may be ischemia leading to Avascular necrosis of hip.
  • • Option C:
  • • Avascular necrosis of the hip could be a late complication
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Dashboard injury is associated with posterior dislocation of hip. Sciatic nerve is commonly involved that leads to foot drop. Avascular necrosis is the common late complication of the injury. The point of impact in this injury is the femur.
  • • Dashboard injury is associated with posterior dislocation of hip.
  • • Sciatic nerve is commonly involved that leads to foot drop.
  • • Avascular necrosis is the common late complication of the injury.
  • • The point of impact in this injury is the femur.

questions.text: A patient presents with hip dislocation with limitation of Abduction at hip, and flexion and internal rotation deformity at hip and shortening. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posterior dislocation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Central dislocation. In central fracture dislocation of hip, femoral head is forced medially through the floor of acetabulum and can be palpated on per rectal examination. There is shortening of limb. This is an extremely rare variety of dislocation.
  • • Option A: Central dislocation.
  • • Option B: Anterior dislocation . Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted. The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head. They are associated with lengthening.
  • • Option B: Anterior dislocation
  • • They are associated with lengthening.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In posterior dislocation of the hip, the hip is in the FADIR deformity i.e., flexion, adduction and internal rotation, along with shortening of the limb.
  • • In posterior dislocation of the hip, the hip is in the FADIR deformity i.e., flexion, adduction and internal rotation, along with shortening of the limb.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with disc prolapse. Examination reveals paralysis of Extensor Hallucis Longus. Which nerve root is affected?
questions.explanation:

  • • Explanation:

  • • Option A. L3.
  • • Option B. L4. When L4 nerve root is affected, there is weakness of tibialis anterior and quadriceps muscles, leading to weak ankle dorsiflexion, hip adduction and knee extension.
  • • Option B. L4.
  • • Option D. S1. When S1 nerve root is affected, gastrocnemius and soleus or flexor hallucis longus; abductor hallucis and gluteus maximus are affected. This leads to weakening of ankle plantarflexion and hip extension .

questions.text: The compression fracture is commonest in:
Skeletal traction is given by:
Contraindication for skin traction is/are:
Spur sign is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acetabular fracture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Supracondylar fracture of humerus. If no fracture line can be identified on the radiological images, indirect signs like anterior or posterior fat pad signs can be seen. Since supracondylar fracture is a transverse or oblique fracture, thus is does not involve spur sign on radiography.
  • • Option A: Supracondylar fracture of humerus.
  • • Option B: Radial head fracture. A fracture of the radial head can sometimes result in a spur sign, especially if there is an associated avulsion fracture of the annular ligament or the adjacent soft tissues. The avulsed fragment may appear as a spur on imaging studies. However, not all radial head fractures present with a spur sign.
  • • Option B: Radial head fracture.
  • • Option C: Fibula fracture. A fibula fracture, particularly at the level of the ankle or distal leg, can sometimes result in a spur sign. This is especially true if the fracture involves the attachment site of the lateral collateral ligament or the biceps femoris tendon, leading to an avulsion-type injury and the formation of a bone spur.
  • • Option C: Fibula fracture.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • An acetabular fracture involves the hip socket can occur due to high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle accidents or falls from a height. These fractures can be complex and involve displacement of bone fragments. The avulsion of the bone appears as a spur-like fragment on the radiograph, thus called spur sign.
  • • An acetabular fracture involves the hip socket can occur due to high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle accidents or falls from a height.
  • • These fractures can be complex and involve displacement of bone fragments.
  • • The avulsion of the bone appears as a spur-like fragment on the radiograph, thus called spur sign.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male sustained fracture neck of femur 1 week back. The treatment of choice is:

options.label: C
options.text: Closed reduction and fixation with three cancellous screws

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hemiarthroplasty

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Excision arthroplasty. It is not typically the treatment of choice for a fractured neck of femur, as it does not address the issue of restoring function to the hip joint.
  • • Option B: Excision arthroplasty.
  • • Option C: Closed reduction and fixation with three cancellous screws. Closed reduction is preferred in cases of patients less than 65 years of age with the fracture sustained < 3 weeks ago. It is not preferred in older patients due to concerns about bone quality and healing capacity.
  • • Option C: Closed reduction and fixation with three cancellous screws.
  • • Option D: Longitudinal skin traction for 6 weeks. While traction can be used as a temporary measure to relieve pain and align the fracture, it is not a definitive treatment for a fractured neck of femur, especially in an elderly patient. Long-term traction can lead to complications such as pressure ulcers and muscle atrophy.
  • • Option D: Longitudinal skin traction for 6 weeks.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The treatment of choice for fracture of femoral neck in an 80-year-old patient is hemiarthroplasty.
  • • The treatment of choice for fracture of femoral neck in an 80-year-old patient is hemiarthroplasty.

questions.text: All of the following are true about fracture of the atlas vertebra, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Jefferson’s fracture is the most common of atlas

options.label: C
options.text: Atlanto-occipital fusion may sometimes be needed

Ans. B) Quadriplegia is seen in 80% cases

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Jefferson’s fracture is the most common of atlas . True. Atlas Fractures caused by high-energy trauma with axial loading in young patients is called Jefferson Fracture.
  • • Option A. Jefferson’s fracture is the most common of atlas
  • • Option C. Atlanto-occipital fusion may sometimes be needed. True. Stable injuries can be treated with immobilization in a cervical collar. Unstable injuries require either halo-vest immobilization or surgical stabilization with a fusion of the atlanto-occipital joint.
  • • Option C. Atlanto-occipital fusion may sometimes be needed.
  • • Option D. CT scans should be done for diagnosis. True. Diagnosis is often missed with plain radiographs so a CT scan may be required to make the diagnosis.
  • • Option D. CT scans should be done for diagnosis.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Fracture of the atlas is not associated with neurological deficits unless it is associated with C2 fractures. The patient may present with neck pain and associated neck muscle spasm.
  • • Fracture of the atlas is not associated with neurological deficits unless it is associated with C2 fractures. The patient may present with neck pain and associated neck muscle spasm.

questions.text: Treatment of choice in fracture neck of femur in a 40-year-old male presenting after 2 days is:

options.label: B
options.text: Closed reduction and Internal fixation by cancellous screws

options.label: C
options.text: Closed reduction and Internal fixation by Austin Moore pins

questions.correct_answer: B. Closed reduction and Internal fixation by cancellous screws
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Closed reduction and Internal fixation by cancellous screws

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Hemiarthroplasty. This is preferred in patients > 65 years of age with no pre-existing arthritis.
  • • Option A: Hemiarthroplasty.
  • • Option C: Closed reduction and internal fixation by Austin Moore pins. Austin Moore pins are commonly used for internal fixation of hip fractures, especially in older adults. They are long, metallic pins inserted into the femoral neck to stabilize the fracture. However, in a 40-year-old male with a fracture neck of femur presenting after only 2 days, internal fixation with Austin Moore pins might not be the treatment of choice. This option is more commonly considered in older patients or in certain fracture patterns where hemiarthroplasty or other methods are not feasible.
  • • Option C: Closed reduction and internal fixation by Austin Moore pins.
  • • Option D: Plaster and rest . Plaster immobilization is not typically indicated for a fracture neck of femur, especially in a 40-year-old male. Fractures in this region usually require surgical intervention for proper alignment and stabilization to prevent complications like avascular necrosis of the femoral head or nonunion. Plaster immobilization alone does not provide adequate stabilization and may lead to poor outcomes.
  • • Option D: Plaster and rest
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In patients < 65 years of age with fracture < 3 weeks old, the preferred treatment option is closed reduction and internal fixation with multiple cancellous screws.
  • • In patients < 65 years of age with fracture < 3 weeks old, the preferred treatment option is closed reduction and internal fixation with multiple cancellous screws.

These injuries typically demonstrate complete bilateral loss of motor function, pain sensation, temperature sensation, proprioception, vibratory sensation, and tactile sensation below the level of injury. Lumbosacral injuries will present with paralysis and loss of sensation in the lower extremities. These injuries may also result in loss of bowel control, loss of bladder control, and sexual dysfunction. Thoracic injuries lead to the same deficits as lumbosacral injuries and, in addition, may result in loss of function of the muscles of the torso, leading to difficulty maintaining posture. Cervical injuries lead to the same deficits as thoracic injuries and, also, may result in loss of function of the upper extremities leading to tetraplegia. Injuries above C5 may also cause respiratory compromise due to loss of innervation of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Most common complication of intertrochanteric fracture femur is:
Trochanteric fracture of femur is best treated by:

options.label: D
options.text: Plaster in abduction and internal rotation

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dynamic hip screw

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Inlay plates. Inlay plates are not used in the treatment of trochanteric fractures of the femur. These fractures usually involve the proximal portion of the femur, such as the greater or lesser trochanter, and are commonly treated with devices specifically designed for stabilization, such as dynamic hip screws or intramedullary nails.
  • • Option B: Inlay plates.
  • • Option C: Plaster in abduction. Plaster immobilization in abduction is not the standard treatment for trochanteric fractures. Trochanteric fractures often require surgical intervention for proper alignment and stabilization, as immobilization in plaster alone may not provide adequate support and could lead to malunion or nonunion.
  • • Option C: Plaster in abduction.
  • • Option D: Plaster in abduction and internal rotation. While immobilizing the limb in abduction might theoretically reduce tension on the fracture site, adding internal rotation is not typically recommended for trochanteric fractures. Internal rotation could potentially worsen the displacement of the fracture fragments or lead to malalignment during the healing process.
  • • Option D: Plaster in abduction and internal rotation.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Trochanteric fractures of the femur are best treated by the dynamic hip screw or proximal femoral nailing as it provides greater stability to the fracture fragments.
  • • Trochanteric fractures of the femur are best treated by the dynamic hip screw or proximal femoral nailing as it provides greater stability to the fracture fragments.

questions.text: Cancellous bone graft is taken from:
Most common type of hip dislocation is:
Denis gave how many columns theory to define stability of spine?
In spinal shock:

options.label: A
options.text: Knee jerk is the first reflex to return

options.label: B
options.text: High thoracic lesions are commonly associated with more severe neurological deficits

options.label: C
options.text: Failure of return of cord activity within 48 hours is a very poor prognostic sign

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both B and C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Knee jerk is the first reflex to return. False. The first reflex to return is bulbocavernosus reflex (S2, S3, S4) – contraction of the anal sphincter in response to the stimulation of glans or clitoris. Its reappearance is the sign of recovery from the spinal shock.
  • • Option A. Knee jerk is the first reflex to return.
  • • Option B. High thoracic lesions are commonly associated with more severe neurological deficits. True. Higher the level of lesion, greater the number of spinal segments involved and more extensive the neurological deficits. Higher thoracic lesions may cause paraplegia, quadriplegia and may also cause autonomic dysfunction such as impaired BP regulation etc. due to involvement of sympathetic nerves.
  • • Option B. High thoracic lesions are commonly associated with more severe neurological deficits.
  • • Option C. Failure of return of cord activity within 48 hours is a very poor prognostic sign . True. The absence of any signs of neurological improvement during first 48 hours is suggestive of severe spinal cord injury and implies a lower chances of significant recovery.
  • • Option C. Failure of return of cord activity within 48 hours is a very poor prognostic sign
  • • Educative objective:
  • • Educative objective:
  • • Spinal injury in first acute phase include neurogenic shock and spinal shock. Neurogenic shock: Hypotension and relative bradycardia Spinal shock: Temporary loss of spinal cord function and reflex activity below the level of spinal cord injury characterized by : Flaccid areflexic paralysis Bradycardia & hypotension (due to loss of sympathetic tone) Absent bulbocavernosus reflex Important to know because one cannot evaluate neurologic deficit until spinal shock phase has resolved. End of spinal shock is indicated by return of the bulbocavernous reflex. Conus medullaris or cauda equina injuries may also lead to permanent loss of the bulbocavernous reflex.
  • • Spinal injury in first acute phase include neurogenic shock and spinal shock.
  • • Neurogenic shock: Hypotension and relative bradycardia
  • • Neurogenic shock:
  • • Spinal shock: Temporary loss of spinal cord function and reflex activity below the level of spinal cord injury characterized by : Flaccid areflexic paralysis Bradycardia & hypotension (due to loss of sympathetic tone) Absent bulbocavernosus reflex
  • • Spinal shock:
  • • characterized by
  • • Flaccid areflexic paralysis Bradycardia & hypotension (due to loss of sympathetic tone) Absent bulbocavernosus reflex
  • • Flaccid areflexic paralysis
  • • Bradycardia & hypotension (due to loss of sympathetic tone)
  • • Absent bulbocavernosus reflex

  • • Option D. Spinous process fracture of C7 vertebra. This type of injury occurs after sudden flexion of the head. It can also occur after repeated stress caused by the pulling of the trapezius and rhomboid muscles on the spinous processes. This injury is known as a “clay shoveler’s fracture”. There is an acute avulsion fracture. The lower cervical or upper thoracic spinous processes are general affected as they have longer and more vulnerable spinous processes. It is usually a very stable fracture and does not produce any neurologic deficits. It typically heals with 6-8 weeks of relative rest with no further treatment being needed in most cases.

questions.text: Block vertebrae are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Klippel-Feil syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Paget’s disease. In paget’s, the vertebral body increases in anteroposterior and lateral dimensions but the height remains unchanged. Early radiographic appearance is thickening and hypertrophy of trabecular bone parallel to the end plate. The combination of trabecular bone hypertrophy and thickening at the end-plates with absorption on the periosteal surfaces at the anterior and posterior vertebral borders leads to the “picture frame” sign.
  • • Option A. Paget’s disease.
  • • Option B. Leukemia . The radiographic changes noted in the vertebrae included diffuse demineralization of the bodies, the neural arches, and the transverse processes. The loss of bone density appeared is more pronounced in the thoracic and the upper lumbar spine. In some cases, demineralization is greater in the centers of the vertebrae than at peripheries. There can be compression of the vertebral bodies, the most common structural change being anterior wedging.
  • • Option B. Leukemia
  • • Option C. TB . In spinal tuberculosis, characteristically, there is destruction of the intervertebral disk space and the adjacent vertebral bodies, collapse of the spinal elements, and anterior wedging leading to the characteristic angulation and gibbus (palpable deformity because of involvement of multiple vertebrae) formation.
  • • Option C. TB

questions.text: Seat belt injury is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chance fracture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Tear drop fracture. Tear drop fracture is a fracture pattern occurring in severe axial/flexion injury of the cervical spine. They indicate extensive underlying ligamentous injury and spinal instability. Associated spinal cord injury is common, especially anterior cervical cord syndrome and quadriplegia.
  • • Option A. Tear drop fracture.
  • • Option B. Wedge fracture. Spinal wedge (compression) fractures are hyperflexion injuries to the vertebral body resulting from axial loading. Most commonly affecting the anterior aspect of the vertebral body, wedge fractures are considered a stable fracture. Most common type (~50%) of thoracolumbar spine fractures. Typically, these fractures are insufficiency fractures secondary to osteoporosis, although some are pathological secondary to a focal bone lesion.
  • • Option B. Wedge fracture.
  • • Option D. Whiplash injury. These are the acceleration-deceleration injuries occurring to the cervical spine. It is caused by neck bending forcibly forward and then backward, or vice versa. The injury, which is poorly understood, usually involves the muscles, discs, nerves, and tendons in neck.
  • • Option D. Whiplash injury.

Most commonly affecting the anterior aspect of the vertebral body, wedge fractures are considered a stable fracture. Most common type (~50%) of thoracolumbar spine fractures. Typically, these fractures are insufficiency fractures secondary to osteoporosis, although some are pathological secondary to a focal bone lesion.
  • • Option A. Wedge compression fracture.
  • • Option B. Axial compression fractures. Compression wedge fractures are caused by axial compression alone or flexion forces, when the spine is bent forward or in side flexion at the moment of trauma. It is a stable fracture and patients rarely accompany neurological deficits. The most common causes in younger patients are falls and motor vehicle accidents.
  • • Option B. Axial compression fractures.

questions.text: ​​​ Line joining anterior superior iliac spine to ischial tuberosity and passing above greater trochanter is called:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nelaton's line

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B: Shoemaker’s line . The line from the tip of Greater Trochanter to the anterior superior iliac spine is prolonged anteriorly to meet in the central line at or above the umbilicus of the patient. If the GT is elevated/proximally migrated, the line will cross the mid line below the umbilicus.
  • • Option B: Shoemaker’s line
  • • Option C: Chiene’s line . 2 lines joining the GT on both sides and ASIS on both sides must be parallel. Supratrochanteric shortening at 1 side leads to convergence of line. This forms a parallelogram called as Chiene’s parallelogram . It is used to detect the femoral head fracture based on the changes in the bony landmark relation. Normally both the lines should be parallel. If GT of one side migrates proximally, as in femoral fracture, the line converges. This test is ineffective in bilateral hip affections.
  • • Option C: Chiene’s line
  • • Chiene’s parallelogram
  • • Option D: Perkin’s line . Perkin line is a line drawn perpendicular to Hilgenreiner line, intersecting the lateral most aspect of the acetabular roof. The upper femoral epiphysis should be seen in the inferomedial quadrant. It should lie below Hilgenreiner line, and medial to Perkin line. If the nucleus of the femoral head is not visible because it is not ossified yet, the femoral metaphysis should be used. Lateral displacement of the femoral head occurs in developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).
  • • Option D: Perkin’s line
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The line joining the ASIS to ischial tuberosity and passes above the greater trochanter is called the Nelaton’s line.
  • • The line joining the ASIS to ischial tuberosity and passes above the greater trochanter is called the Nelaton’s line.

questions.text: Trendelenburg’s sign is negative in an Inter-Trochanteric fracture because of:
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

  • • Option A: Gluteus medius . The gluteus medius is one of the primary abductor muscles of the hip. If it is weak or dysfunctional, it can lead to a positive Trendelenburg sign.
  • • Option A: Gluteus medius
  • • Option B: Gluteus maximus . The gluteus maximus is primarily involved in hip extension and external rotation. While it is an important muscle around the hip joint, weakness or dysfunction in the gluteus maximus is not typically associated with Trendelenburg's sign.
  • • Option B: Gluteus maximus
  • • Option C: Gluteus minimus . The gluteus minimus, along with the gluteus medius, is also involved in hip abduction. Dysfunction or weakness in the gluteus minimus can contribute to a positive Trendelenburg sign, not a negative one.
  • • Option C: Gluteus minimus
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The tensor fascia lata is a muscle that assists in hip flexion and stabilization of the pelvis during walking. Dysfunction in the tensor fascia lata can lead to a negative Trendelenburg sign. This is because if the tensor fascia lata is unable to stabilize the pelvis on the unsupported side during single-leg stance, the pelvis may tilt upward rather than dropping, resulting in a negative Trendelenburg sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about intracapsular fracture of femur neck?

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: Contour of greater trochanter is normal

options.label: D
options.text: Tenderness is mainly present over the anterior joint line

Ans. B) Malunion is common complication

  • • Tenderness is mainly present over the anterior joint line:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The most common complication of fracture neck of femur is the non-union of the fracture. There is absence of cambium layer of periostium in the femoral neck within the joint capsule. Thus, the fracture neck of femur heals without external callus. Blood supply is precarious in this region which is further jeopardized by displacement of fragments and a tamponade effect adds to the insult by occluding the veins at lower pressure and arteries at higher pressure. Being intracapsular, the fracture is bathed by synovial fluid which interferes with the healing process.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of fall, complaints of pain in right hip and inability to walk. On examination, tenderness is present in Scarpa’s triangle. The X-ray is normal. Next investigation is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MRI

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Aspiration. Aspiration involves the removal of fluid from a joint or tissue for diagnostic purposes. While it may be indicated in suspected joint effusion or infection, it's not the most appropriate next step in this case, where the primary concern seems to be related to the hip and surrounding structures.
  • • Option A: Aspiration.
  • • Option B: CT scan. CT scan provides detailed images of bones and can reveal fractures or bone abnormalities that may not be apparent on X-ray. However, in this case, where soft tissue involvement is suspected (tenderness in Scarpa's triangle), CT scan might not be the most informative initial investigation for assessing soft tissue pathology.
  • • Option B: CT scan.
  • • Option D: Bone scan. Bone scan is primarily used to detect abnormalities in bone metabolism and is helpful in diagnosing fractures, infections, or tumors that may not be visible on conventional X-rays. However, given the clinical presentation with tenderness in Scarpa's triangle and normal X-ray, the concern seems to be more focused on soft tissue involvement rather than purely bone pathology, making MRI a more appropriate choice for further investigation.
  • • Option D: Bone scan.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In the given case scenario, the injury is around the hip involving soft tissues and bone. The presenting complaints and examination suggests the presence of occult fracture around the hip. The occult fractures are not visible on x-rays and CT scans. They can be only viewed on MRI. Thus, in this case, the next investigation will be an MRI.
  • • In the given case scenario, the injury is around the hip involving soft tissues and bone.
  • • The presenting complaints and examination suggests the presence of occult fracture around the hip.
  • • The occult fractures are not visible on x-rays and CT scans.
  • • They can be only viewed on MRI.
  • • Thus, in this case, the next investigation will be an MRI.

  • • Educational objective:
  • • The Vascular sign of Narath is positive in cases of posterior hip dislocation where the femoral artery is not palpable or has feeble pulsations.

questions.text: Maximum shortening of limbs occurs in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Intertrochanteric fracture femur. This fracture also presents with limb shortening but it is not more than that seen in the posterior hip dislocation.
  • • Option A: Intertrochanteric fracture femur.
  • • Option C: Fracture neck of femur. The impacted and stress fractures of the femoral neck do not present with any limb deformity. The displaced femoral neck fractures present with limb shortening but it is not more than that seen in posterior hip dislocation.
  • • Option C: Fracture neck of femur.
  • • Option D: Anterior dislocation of hip. This dislocation presents with lengthening of the limb due to anterior position of the displaced femoral head.
  • • Option D: Anterior dislocation of hip.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Maximum limb shortening is seen in the posterior dislocation of the hip due to the posterior placement of the femoral head after dislocation.
  • • Maximum limb shortening is seen in the posterior dislocation of the hip due to the posterior placement of the femoral head after dislocation.
